'''''Empire Endurance''''' was a {{GRT|8,514}} [[cargo liner]] that was built in 1928 as '''''Alster''''' by [[Deutsche Schiff- und Maschinenbau|Deschimag Werk Vulkan]], [[Hamburg]], Germany for the shipping company [[Norddeutscher Lloyd]]. In the years leading up to the [[World War II|Second World War]] ''Alster'' carried cargo and passengers between Germany and Australia. After the outbreak of war she was requisitioned by the [[Kriegsmarine]] for use as a supply ship.
''Alster'' was captured off Norway on 10 April 1940 by the British destroyer {{HMS|Icarus|D03|6}}. Initially serving under the original name as a repair, supply and cargo ship in Norway, she was later passed to the [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) and renamed ''Empire Endurance''. She served until 20 April 1941 when she was [[torpedo]]ed and sunk by the German submarine {{GS|U-73|1940|2}} south-east of the islet of [[Rockall]] in the North Atlantic Ocean.
==Description== The ship was a {{GRT|8,514}} [[cargo liner]]. She was built in 1928 by [[Deutsche Schiff- und Maschinenbau|Deschimag Werk Vulkan]], [[Hamburg]] as ''Alster'',<ref name=Uboat/><ref name=kludas>Kludas 1998, p. 64</ref><ref name=Alster30>{{cite web|url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0049.pdf |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers & Motorships |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> with yard number 211.<ref name=kludas/><ref name=Miramar>{{csr|register=MSI|id=1164841|shipname=Alster |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref>
''Alster'' was {{convert|509.9|ft|m|2}} long, with a beam of {{convert|63.6|ft|m|2}}. She had a depth of {{convert|30.9|ft|m|2}}<!--, and a draught of {{convert|xx|ft|x|in|m|2}}-->. She was assessed at {{GRT|8,514}}, {{NRT|5,328}},<ref name=Alster30/> 12,000 [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]].<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref> She had four [[Mast (sailing)|masts]], a single [[Chimney|funnel]], a round [[stern]] and a slanted [[Stem (ship)|stem]].<ref>Schwadtke 1974, p. 137</ref>
The ship was propelled by a 1,000 [[nominal horsepower|nhp]] [[triple expansion steam engine]], which had cylinders of {{convert|31+1/4|in|cm}}, {{convert|52+3/4|in|cm}} and {{convert|86+5/6|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|57+1/16|in|cm|0}} stroke. The engine was also made by the shipbuilder.<ref name=Alster30/> A low pressure [[steam turbine]] drove the ship's single screw propeller through double reduction gearing and a hydraulic coupling.<ref name=Endurance40/> She had a total of 6,500 [[indicated horsepower]], which gave her a top speed of {{convert|14|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=kludas/><ref name=Miramar/><ref name=schwadtke689>Schwadtke 1974, p. 68-69</ref>
==History== ''Alster'' was launched on 5 January 1928, and completed on 25 February 1928.<ref name=Uboat>{{cite web |url=http://uboat.net/allies/merchants/ships/881.html |title=Empire Endurance |publisher=Uboat |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref><ref name=kludas/> She was built for [[Norddeutscher Lloyd]].<ref name=Ships/> The [[Code Letters]] QMHG were allocated and her port of registry was [[Bremen]].<ref name=Alster30/> She served on routes between Germany and Australia and [[East Asia]].<ref name=kludas/><ref name=Times070828>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Shipping |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=7 August 1928 |page_number=2 |issue=44962 |column=B }}</ref> [[Lloyds Register]] entries show that she held a passenger certificate from 1934–40. With the change in Code Letters in 1934, ''Alster'' was allocated DOEO as her callsign.<ref name=Alster37>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0040.pdf |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers & Motorships |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> She had a crew of 69 and could initially take 14 passengers. In 1930 the passenger capacity was increased to 16.<ref name=kludas/><ref name=schwadtke689/>
===Norwegian Campaign and capture=== On 18 March 1940, ''Alster'' was requisitioned by the Kriegsmarine. She was used as a supply ship in [[Operation Weserübung]] - the German invasion of Norway, forming part of the invasion's {{lang|de|''Ausfuhr-Staffel''}}, transporting heavy equipment.<ref name=Uboat/><ref name=bcruiser>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xDKWD-HF1940BCS1B.htm |title=Admiralty War Diaries of World War 2: Vice Admiral, Battlecruiser Squadron, Home Fleet - May to December 1940 |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=16 July 2011 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.niehorster.org/011_germany/40-04_scandinavia/navy_ausfuhr.html |title=Scandinavian Campaign: Equipment Transport Echelon |accessdate=28 June 2015 |last=Niehorster |first=Leo |authorlink=Leo Niehorster}}</ref> ''Alster'' departed [[Brunsbüttel]] at 02:00 on 3 April, destined for the [[Northern Norway|North Norwegian]] port of [[Narvik]]. She was one of four supply ships sailing from the [[Schleswig-Holstein Province|Schleswig-Holstein]] port in support of German forces landing at Narvik on 9 April, under cover of sailing to [[Murmansk]] in the Soviet Union.<ref>Sandvik 1965 vol. 1, p. 135</ref> None of these ships made it to their destination.{{#tag:ref|The three other supply ships sailing from Brunsbüttel were {{SS|Bärenfels|1921|2}}, ''Kattegat'' and {{SS|Rauenfels|1928|2}}. In addition to these, the tanker ''Jan Wellem'' sailed from the German [[Basis Nord]] near Murmansk. ''Jan Wellem'' was the only German supply ship to reach its destination before the invasion began. While ''Alster'' was captured, ''Bärenfels'' was redirected to Bergen, ''Kattegat'' was sunk by the Norwegian patrol boat {{HNoMS|Nordkapp}} and ''Rauenfels'' was knocked out by the destroyer {{HMS|Havock|H43|6}}.<ref>Lunde 2009, pp. 188–189</ref><ref>Haarr 2009, pp. 66, 68</ref>|group=Note}} The lack of supplies and artillery would leave the German forces [[Battles of Narvik|fighting at Narvik]] vulnerable. Upon reaching Norwegian waters, ''Alster'' and the tanker [[MS Kattegat (1928)|''Kattegat'']], also bound for Narvik, was escorted by the Norwegian torpedo boat [[HNoMS Trygg (1919)|HNoMS ''Trygg'']] as far as [[Kopervik]], where they arrived on 5 April. At Kopervik the German plans suffered a delay because of a lack of [[Maritime pilot|pilots]] to guide the ship northwards, ''Alster'' continuing later that day, while ''Kattegat'' departed Kopervik only on 6 April. Many of the other supply ships sent out in advance of the invasion also suffered delays, putting the supply part of the invasion plans out of schedule.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://naval-history.net/xDKWW2-4004-13APR01.htm |title=Naval Events, April 1940, Part 1 of 4 Monday 1st – Sunday 7th |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=17 September 2008 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref><ref name=Steen43>Steen 1958, p. 43</ref> While at Kopervik, ''Alster'' and ''Kattegat'' were inspected by the torpedo boat {{HNoMS|Stegg|1921|6}}, the Norwegians finding nothing irregular.<ref name=Steen43/> By 8 April, ''Alster'' had reached [[Vestfjorden (Norway)|Vestfjorden]], where she was hailed by the Norwegian patrol boat {{HNoMS|Syrian}}, which warned her of the British naval minefield [[Operation Wilfred|laid in the area]] earlier that day. ''Alster'' steamed to Bodø, to await developments. Two days later, on 10 April, following the outbreak of war between Norway and Germany the previous day, ''Syrian'' was despatched to seize ''Alster'' off Bodø. When ''Syrian'' found ''Alster'', the commander of the small Norwegian patrol boat chose not to board the German vessel as he suspected she was armed and possibly carrying troops. As ''Alster'' attempted to escape, ''Syrian'' sent out messages to the British warships in the area.<ref name=april2>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xDKWW2-4004-13APR02.htm |title=Naval Events, April 1940, Part 2 of 4 Monday 8th - Sunday 14th |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=17 September 2008 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref><ref>Berg and Vollan 1999, pp. 66–67</ref><ref>Haarr 2009, pp. 66, 333</ref><ref name=Pedersen224>Pedersen 2009, p. 224</ref><ref>Steen 1958, p. 170</ref>
On 10 April, ''Alster'' was captured by the British destroyer {{HMS|Icarus|D03|6}} in Vestfjorden, north of Bodø. When intercepted the German crew made an unsuccessful attempt at scuttling the vessel, setting off one explosive charge.<ref name=Uboat/><ref name=Ships/><ref name=bcruiser/><ref name=april2/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wlb-stuttgart.de/seekrieg/verluste/ausl%2Bdtsch-4012.htm |title=Verluste Deutscher Handelsschiffe 1939-1945 und unter deutscher Flagge fahrender ausländischer Schiffe: 1940 |last=Rohwer |first=Jürgen |author2=Gerhard Hümmelchen |work=Württembergische Landesbibliothek Stuttgart |publisher= |accessdate=10 March 2012 |language=German}}</ref> The light cruiser {{HMS|Penelope|97|6}} had also been sent after ''Alster'', but had run aground near Bodø and suffered serious damage.<ref>Derry 1952, pp. 46-47</ref> With the British capture of ''Alster'', no more German supply ships were heading for Narvik and the forces there,<ref name="Lunde 2009, p. 253">Lunde 2009, p. 253</ref> leaving General [[Eduard Dietl]]'s troops with the supplies on board the tanker [[SS Jan Wellem (1935)|''Jan Wellem'']] and the large stockpiles of weapons, ammunition, uniforms and food captured at the [[Norwegian Army]] base [[Elvegårdsmoen]].<ref>Sandvik 1965 vol. 1, pp. 214–15</ref> At the time of her capture, ''Alster'' was under the command of ''[[Kapitän]]'' [[Oskar Scharf]], who had previously commanded the [[Blue Riband|Blue Riband-holding]] [[ocean liner]] {{SS|Europa|1928|2}}.<ref name=Times220440>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=British Naval Actions at Narvik: Further Pictures |day_of_week=Monday |date=22 April 1940 |page_number=10 |issue=48596 |column=A-F }}</ref>{{#tag:ref|Commodore Oskar Scharf was taken from Norway by the British as a prisoner of war, eventually ending up as the leader of the prisoners of war held in [[List of World War II prisoner-of-war camps in Canada|Camp R]] in [[Red Rock, Ontario]], having been brought to Canada on the liner [[SS Duchess of York (1928)|''Duchess of York'']].<ref>Koch 1985, pp. 110–112</ref>|group=Note}} Initially ''Alster'' was brought to the improvised British naval base at [[Skjelfjorden|Skjelfjord]] in [[Lofoten]].<ref name=bcruiser/> On arrival at Skjelfjord on 11 April, a prize crew from ''Penelope'' took over responsibility for the ship.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xDKWD-HF1940CS2.htm |title=Admiralty War Diaries of World War 2: Rear Admiral, Second (2nd) Cruiser Squadron - March to December 1940 |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=16 July 2011 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref> At Skjelfjord, the captured German crew made an unsuccessful attempt at scuttling ''Alster'' by opening the ship's [[sea valve]]s.<ref name=Pedersen224/> While at Skjelfjord ''Alster'', being equipped with [[derrick]]s, was used to help repair damaged Allied warships. One of the vessels on which emergency repairs were carried out from ''Alster'', was the destroyer {{HMS|Eskimo|F75|6}}, which had lost her bow during the naval battles off Narvik.<ref>Haarr 2009, pp. 353, 370</ref><ref>Haarr 2010, p. 212</ref> ''Alster'' was also used as an accommodation ship for the crews of the damaged vessels at Skjelfjord.<ref>Haarr 2010, p. 216</ref> On 24 April ''Alster'' departed Skjelfjord for the Northern Norwegian port of [[Tromsø]], manned by a British prize crew.<ref>Haarr 2010, p. 217</ref><ref name=Steen171>Steen 1958, p. 171</ref> The eight German officers captured on ''Alster'' were transferred to the United Kingdom on the British destroyers {{HMS|Cossack|F03|6}} and {{HMS|Punjabi||6}}.<ref>Haarr 2010, p. 433</ref> In all, 80 Germans were captured on board ''Alster'', and all were eventually sent to the United Kingdom.<ref name=Steen171/>
Her cargo of 88 [[Truck|lorries]], anti-aircraft guns, spare parts for aircraft, ammunition, communications equipment, [[Coke (fuel)|coke]] and 400–500 tons of hay, was unloaded in Tromsø on 27 April, as part of the Allied support of the Norwegian forces [[Norwegian Campaign|fighting]] the German invasion of their country. The cargo was put to use in the supply and defence of the Tromsø area, except for the hay, which was quarantined by the Norwegian authorities at [[Ringvassøy]] for fear of [[foot-and-mouth disease]].<ref name=Chrispeder>Christensen and Pedersen 1995, pp. 413–15</ref><ref>Haarr 2010, p. 265</ref><ref>Sandvik 1965 vol. 1, p. 202</ref><ref name=sandvik1612>Sandvik 1965 vol. 2, pp. 161–62</ref> The coke on board ''Alster'' had been placed by the Germans in a {{convert|6|ft|m|2|abbr=on}} layer covering the deck.<ref>Walker 1989, p. 18</ref> The supplies on ''Alster'' were transferred to the Norwegians by the Allied naval commander [[William Boyle, 12th Earl of Cork and Orrery|Lord Cork]] after the Norwegian authorities had made repeated request for weapons and other war matériel, and was intended to be a first effort before the arrival of larger quantities of arms and ammunition promised to the Norwegians.<ref name=sandvik1612/>{{#tag:ref|Northern Norway at the time of the 1940 Norwegian Campaign had no capacity for weapons or ammunition manufacture. The only ammunition available to the Norwegian forces fighting in Northern Norway came from pre-war stocks in military depots. As the campaign progressed artillery ammunition started running low, and ammunition for machine guns and rifles almost ran out.<ref name="Lunde 2009, p. 253"/>|group=Note}}{{#tag:ref|The first and only regular transfer of weapons from the British military to their Norwegian counterparts occurred on 31 May, when 5,000 rifles, 100 [[Bren light machine gun]]s and 500,000 rounds of ammunition were handed over.<ref name=sandvik185>Sandvik 1965 vol. 2, p. 185</ref>|group=Note}} The lorries and weapons from ''Alster'' were received, assessed and distributed by Norwegian military personnel under the command of Major [[Karl Arnulf]], who had arrived in Tromsø on 7 May 1940, having made his way from German-occupied [[South Norway]].<ref name=sandvik185/> The communications equipment included both a mobile radio transmitter, which was used as a spare for Tromsø radio broadcasting station, as well as large quantities of [[field telephone]] equipment which was sent to the units of the Norwegian [[6th Division (Norway)|6th Division]] on the Narvik front. The field equipment from ''Alster'' replaced the old and worn field telephone systems in use up to that point. Training on the German equipment was provided by Swedish volunteers.<ref name=Chrispeder/><ref>Sandvik 1965 vol. 2, p. 183</ref> While docked in Tromsø in May 1940, ''Alster'' had 70 captive Germans on board.<ref name=1stcruiser>{{cite web |url=http://naval-history.net/xDKWD-HF1940CS1.htm |title=Admiralty War Diaries of World War 2: Rear Admiral, First (1st) Cruiser Squadron - March to August 1940 |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=16 July 2011 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref> At Tromsø, ''Alster'' was manned by Norwegian sailors, replacing the British prize crew.<ref name=Steen171/>
On 16 May a request was made to the [[Admiralty]] for a call sign for ''Alster'', the ship departing Tromsø the next day for [[Kirkenes]] in [[Finnmark]], escorted by the [[Anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine]] whaler {{HMS|Ullswater||6}}. She was despatched to the northern port to retrieve a cargo of [[iron ore]]. Arriving on 19 May 1940, ''Alster'' loaded some 10,000 tons of iron ore over four days, sailing south to the port of [[Harstad]] on 22 May, still escorted by HMS ''Ullswater'', as well as the Norwegian patrol boat {{HNoMS|Nordhav II}}. On 23 May, the British submarine [[HMS Truant (N68)|HMS ''Truant'']] made an unsuccessful attack with two torpedoes on ''Alster'' off [[Havøya]], despite efforts having been made to both keep the cargo ship away from the submarine's patrol area, and to warn ''Truant'' of the ship's identity. The torpedoes missed, exploding when they hit land. ''Alster'' and HMS ''Ullswater'' arrived at Harstad on 26 May, with the escort vessel sailing northwards to [[Hammerfest]] with mail and provisions for the heavy cruiser {{HMS|Devonshire|39|6}}.<ref name=1stcruiser/><ref>Haarr 2010, p. 263</ref><ref>Steen 1958, p. 251</ref> While ''Alster'' was at Harstad shipping in the town's harbour was repeatedly subjected to attacks by ''[[Luftwaffe]]'' [[Heinkel He 111]] bombers, the ships being defended by [[Gloster Gladiator]] fighters of the [[No. 263 Squadron RAF]] operating from [[Bardufoss Air Station]] and anti-aircraft artillery. During one of the attacks on 26 May the ship's Norwegian [[Fireman (steam engine)|fireman]] was mortally wounded by [[Fragmentation (weaponry)|bomb fragments]], dying in [[Harstad Hospital]] later the same day.<ref>Ingebrigtsen 1995, pp. 182–183</ref><ref>Ording 1950, p. 794</ref><ref>Hafsten 1991, p. 95–96</ref>
On 27 May ''Alster'' sailed for the United Kingdom in a five-ship convoy which included the crippled HMS ''Eskimo''. In addition to her cargo of iron ore, the ship carried 209 British military personnel, 46 Norwegian military personnel and 72 German [[Prisoner of war|prisoners of war]]. She also transported the "B" gun turret from ''Eskimo'', which had been removed from the destroyer during makeshift repairs. ''Alster'' arrived at [[Scapa Flow]] on 31 May, unloading her passengers there. Sailing on 3 June, in the company of the passenger steamer {{SS|St. Magnus|1924|2}} and escorted by the destroyers {{HMS|Ashanti|F51|6}} and {{HMS|Bedouin|F67|6}}, she arrived at [[Rosyth]] in Scotland on 4 June 1940.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xDKWW2-4005-14MAY04.htm |title=Naval Events, May 1940, Part 4 of 4 Wednesday 22nd – Friday 31st |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=17 September 2008 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://naval-history.net/xDKWW2-4006-19JUN01.htm |title=Naval Events, June 1940, Part 1 of 4 Saturday 1st – Friday 7th |accessdate=8 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=19 April 2009 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref><ref>Haarr 2010, p. 436</ref>
===As Empire Endurance=== {{location map|North Atlantic|width=304 |lat=53.083 |long=-23.233 |caption=Location where ''Empire Endurance'' was torpedoed and sunk. }} {{See also|Empire ship}} ''Alster'' was passed to the MoWT and renamed ''Empire Endurance''.<ref name=Ships/> The United Kingdom Official Number 164841 and Code Letters GMJJ were allocated. Her port of registry was [[Middlesbrough]]. She was placed under the management of the Booth Steamship Co Ltd.<ref name=Endurance40>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=40b1057.pdf |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers & Motorships |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> ''Empire Endurance'' was a member of Convoy FN 255, which departed from [[Southend-on-Sea|Southend]], [[Essex]] on 17 August and arrived at [[Methil]], [[Fife]] two days later.<ref name=FN255>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/fn/index.html?fn.php?convoy=0255!~fnmain |title=Convoy FN.255 = Convoy FN.55 / Phase 3|publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> She then joined Convoy OA 202, which departed on 21 August and dispersed at sea on 25 August.<ref name=OA202>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/oa/index.html?oa.php?convoy=202!~oamain |title=Convoy OA.202 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> Her destination was [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada, where she arrived on 3 September. ''Empire Endurance'' sailed on 12 September for [[Sydney, Nova Scotia|Sydney]], [[Cape Breton Island|Cape Breton]], [[Nova Scotia]], arriving three days later.<ref name=Port>{{cite web |url=http://convoyweb.org.uk/ports/index.html?search.php?vessel=EMPIRE%20ENDURANCE~armain |title=Empire Endurance |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> She then joined Convoy HX 74, which departed from [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], Nova Scotia on 17 September and arrived at [[Liverpool]], [[Lancashire]], United Kingdom on 2 October. She was carrying general cargo stated to be bound for [[Newcastle-upon-Tyne]], [[Northumberland]].<ref name=HX74>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx74.html |title=Convoy HX 74 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> She left the convoy at the [[River Clyde|Clyde]] on 2 October.<ref name=Port/>
''Empire Endurance'' departed on 25 October to join Convoy OB 234,<ref name=Port/> which had departed from Liverpool the previous day and dispersed at sea on 30 October.<ref name=OB234>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/ob2/index.html?ob.php?convoy=234!~obmain |title=Convoy OB.234 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> Her destination was Montreal, where she arrived on 6 November. She departed on 18 November for the Clyde, arriving on 27 November.<ref name=Port/> The ship was declared a [[prize of war]] on 10 December 1940, valued at [[Pound Sterling|£144,000]].<ref name=Times111240>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Prize Court |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=11 December 1940 |page_number=2 |issue=48796 |column=G }}</ref> She departed on 5 January 1941 to join Convoy OB 270,<ref name=Port/> which had departed from Liverpool that day and dispersed at sea on 8 January.<ref name=OB270>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/ob2/index.html?ob.php?convoy=270!~obmain |title=Convoy OB.270 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> She sailed to [[Saint John, New Brunswick]], Canada, arriving on 17 January. ''Empire Endurance'' sailed on 3 February for Halifax, arriving two days later and departing on 9 February for the Clyde, where she arrived on 21 February.<ref name=Port/>
''Empire Endurance'' departed on 23 February for [[Swansea]], [[Glamorgan]], arriving on 1 March. She sailed on 9 March for [[Avonmouth]], [[Somerset]], arriving the next day. She departed on 29 March for [[Cardiff]], Glamorgan, arriving the next day and sailing on 2 April for [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[Monmouthshire (historic)|Monmouthshire]], where she arrived later that day. She sailed on 13 April for [[Milford Haven]], [[Pembrokeshire]], where she arrived on 15 April.<ref name=Port/>
On 19 April, ''Empire Endurance'' departed from Milford Haven,<ref name=Port/> bound for [[Cape Town]], South Africa and [[Alexandria]], Egypt. She was manned by 90 crew and had five passengers on board. Amongst her cargo were the [[Fairmile B motor launch]]es ''ML-1003'' and ''ML-1037''. At 03:32 (German time) on 20 April, ''Empire Endurance'' was hit amidships by a [[torpedo]] fired by {{GS|U-73|1940|2}}, under the command of [[Helmut Rosenbaum]]. At the time she was south west of [[Rockall]] at {{coord|53|05|N|23|14|W|display=inline, title}}. A ''[[coup de grâce]]'' was fired at 03:57 which hit just under the bridge, breaking her in two. ''Empire Endurance'' sank with the loss of 65 crew and one passenger. Among the crew members lost was the captain, Fred J.S. Tucker of the [[Royal Naval Reserve]]. On 21 April, the Canadian [[Flower class corvette|Flower class]] corvette {{HMCS|Trillium|K172|6}} picked up twenty crew and four passengers at {{coord|52|50|N|22|50|W}}. They were landed at [[Greenock]], [[Renfrewshire (historic)|Renfrewshire]] on 25 May. On 9 May, five crew were rescued by the British cargo liner {{MV|Highland Brigade||2}}. They were landed at Liverpool.<ref name=Uboat/> Those lost on board ''Empire Endurance'' are commemorated on the [[Tower Hill Memorial]], [[London]].<ref name=Benjidog>{{cite web |url=http://www.benjidog.co.uk/Tower%20Hill/Empire%20Day%20to%20Empire%20Engineer.html |title=Empire Day to Empire Engineer |publisher=Brian Watson |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xDKCas1941-04APR.htm |title=Casualty Lists of the Royal Navy and Dominion Navies, World War 2 – 1st - 30th April 1941 - in date, ship/unit & name order |accessdate=9 March 2012 |last=Kindell |first=Don |date=18 April 2009 |work=Naval-History.net }}</ref>
